text: Philip maybe you could tell us a bit
about what because it's not a subtle
difference what is a neuroprosthetic
sure so when you think about modulation
basically what you're talking about is a
circuit that's sort of off-kilter it's
out of back it's oscillating at the
wrong frequencies or it's sending the
wrong patterns and what you want to do
is somehow try to move it back into the
right operating regime if you will when
we talk about a prosthetic device
generally usually what we're thinking
about is replacing something something
that's missing something that's broken
restoring function replacing a part a
prosthetic heart right putting in a new
heart and so on and so when you think
about a neuro prosthetic what we usually
think about is replacing lost function
and there are many examples of neural
prosthetics the earliest one of course
is the is the cochlear implant to
replace hearing for those whose cochlea
aren't working right and now there are
also fda-approved and in Europe proof or
even longer retinal implants that do the
same sort of thing that stimulate tissue
in the periphery in the eye or in the
ear in order to replace vision or
audition but these days sort of the new
frontier really is thinking about
brain implants so these are implants
that would go into the brain that would
replace lost function and there are a
number of examples of that the one
that's probably furthest along is a
motor prosthetic so this is for people
say for example who have spinal cord
injury or who have ALS Lou Gehrig's
disease who are paralyzed and can't move
their bodies and then what you could do
is you can put a set of electrodes say
in in motor cortex which is the part of
the brain on the superficial part of the
brain up here that normally activates in
order to control limb or muscles lower
limb upper limb the rest of our body and
you can read out
activity from those neurons and use that
to infer what it is that the patient
wanted to do and then use a machine or a
computer to control some external device
that would replace function so that
could be a robotic limb it could be a
computer interface like a cursor and it
could be a wheelchair could be in may
have seen recently in the news there
were some news about stimulating muscles
so it could even be functional
electrical stimulation of the muscle to
reanimate but a patient's own limb
and so when I talk about a motor per set
/ CSIS that's usually what what we think
about
[Music]
